item.title: New York Times Connections Hints and Answers for #386 July 1, 2024
item.description:
Connections is a daily word puzzle game where you need to sort words into mystery categories. In order to win this challenging game, you'll need to know a whole lot more than just the rules of how to play Connections ; you will also need to know all the categories, and you'll probably need a little luck as well.

If your luck is running low, however, you can find all the help you'll need to solve this challenging word puzzle in the article below. Here you'll find general hints, clues to the categories, spoilers, and even the whole answer.

Words in the NYT Connections Puzzle #386 for July 1, 2024

The Connections puzzle for today contains the words: Pyramid, Prince, British, Seal, Sting, Washington, Nova, Usher, Northwest, Racket, Lead, Eagle, Con, Direct, Hustle, and Guide.

Hints for the NYT Connections Puzzle

Hints for this challenging mobile puzzle game can be found in the sections below. Each section is covered up, so you must press the Read More button below the section you want to see.

Some General Hints for the Whole Connections Puzzle

Yellow NYT Connections Category Hints

Yellow Connections Category Answer

Yellow Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Green NYT Connections Category Hints

Green Connections Category Answer

Green Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Blue NYT Connections Category Hints

Blue Connections Category Answer

Blue Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Purple NYT Connections Category Hints

Purple Connections Category Answer

Purple Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Answers for Today's NYT Connections #386 for July 1, 2024

Below, you can find the New York Times Games Connections answer. Press the Read More button below to see it in full.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Connections website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Star Wars Outlaws’ Season Pass May Prematurely Ensure Kay Vess’ Fate
item.description:
Highlights

  • Star Wars Outlaws' Gold and Ultimate editions include a season pass with two story DLCs.
  • Protagonist Kay Vess' survival in the story is likely if it is presumed that she is reprised for these DLCs.

Star Wars Outlaws has dropped quite a bit of gameplay footage since its reveal. Not a lot of it has offered new content that earlier footage hadn’t shown, however, and nothing new can be gleaned from its story besides the fact that Kay and Nix have been companions since Kay was young. Star Wars Outlaws certainly runs the risk of being transparent to a fault at the moment with thinly articulated features and a core loop of stealth, but the game’s launch at the end of August still has a chance to prove that theory wrong.

Thankfully, that’s not all there is to look forward to in Star Wars Outlaws . Beyond its base game, Star Wars Outlaws ’ Gold and Ultimate editions come packaged with a season pass including two story-related DLCs. It’s unknown how expansive they will be or if they’re connected to one another and yet it’s a telling sign for the game’s narrative that it won’t close the book on certain events until after launch, assuming it does continue from where Outlaws ’ base game ends. But if there will be two story-related DLCs and presumably no additional playable protagonists, Kay seems guaranteed to make it out of Outlaws ’ golden path alive.

Star Wars Outlaws’ Season Pass Story Packs Suggest Kay Gets an Upper Hand

A recent Game Rant interview with Outlaws creative director Julian Gerighty states that the game is “family-friendly,” but a character’s self-sacrifice for a greater good could still be Kay’s fate, especially if she’s fighting for a cause that she deems greater than herself by the end. Outlaws has made no attempt to reveal some underlying ambition of Kay’s aside from her trying to make it day by day, though, and maybe that’s as paper-thin as her character motivations will be throughout.

Either way, her death is made even more unlikely with two story DLCs in Outlaws ’ season pass. Right now, the season pass story packs are only described as allowing players to “keep exploring the world of Star Wars Outlaws with all-new stories, quests and areas to discover” as per the game’s official website.

Another reason why Kay’s fate being unambiguous would be underwhelming is because the stakes that her crime syndicate-related adventures may have had are gone if there is no possibility of those scoundrel ties coming back to bite her in the end. For Kay to dabble in all of Star Wars ’ most notorious criminal organizations throughout the galaxy during the Age of Rebellion era without the threat of huge consequences is a letdown because it makes each syndicate that’s unable to challenge or defeat her less intimidating.

Outlaws doesn’t necessarily need to conclude with Kay having enraged a rival faction or a particular group’s leader, but Kay finding herself embroiled in the life of a scoundrel and the lives of Star Wars ’ shadiest inhabitants should mean that it wouldn’t be so easy to make it out alive, much less not make any enemies along the way who want to thwart her happy ending.

Star Wars Outlaws’ Story Packs Don’t Necessarily Need to Feature Kay Vess

That said, it’s not completely out of the realm of possibility that Kay could die in Outlaws : one of these DLCs could be a prequel entry and thus feature Kay before her possible demise in Outlaws , for example, and one could feature a new protagonist. Knowing that there are two DLCs planned gives Outlaws an interesting post-launch shelf life and having that not include Kay would be absurd given how all of the game’s mechanics revolve around her and Nix exclusively, making a prequel chapter the more likely option of the two anyhow.

If Outlaws is being developed with franchise potential in mind like Star Wars Jedi , it’d make sense for Massive to invest fully in Kay and Nix—as well as ND-5, maybe—as its mascots like Cal Kestis and BD-1. Ultimately, if Kay and Nix are lured back via DLC it probably means they are unsuccessful in securing their earnings from whatever heist journey it is they carelessly decide to embark upon, and future story content will need a valid and meaningful excuse as to why they might still be at the mercy of the galaxy’s criminal underbelly.

item.title: Pokemon Evolution Methods, Ranked
item.description:
One of the most well-known aspects of the Pokemon series is evolution, where Pokemon can grow into stronger forms with their trainer's assistance. Since the inception of the series, not every Pokemon has evolved the same, and in each generation, newer, more specific methods have appeared as well.

Rather than trying to parse their merits, these methods will be ranked by convenience, as some are easier than others. To simplify the process, certain more specific methods will be lumped in with their more common counterparts, as they often rely on the simpler methods, just with extra steps included.

14 Collect-a-thon

Evolves: Gimmighoul and Meltan (Pokemon Go only)

  • Originated in Pokemon Go

Perhaps the least convenient method is the admittedly rare, collect-a-thon. Most Pokemon only take one item to evolve. A few, however, require the accumulation of numerous evolutionary items, all directed towards one specific Pokemon. This is relatively less convenient than most other methods.

Gimmighoul requires 999 Gimmighoul coins, which are found throughout Paldea, often atop taller structures. Meltan is an even odder prospect, as its evolution requires Pokemon Go, where it can either be evolved by way of a mystery box given to owners of Let's Go Pikachu and Let's Go Eevee or 400 Meltan Candy, which can be collected in Go proper.

In both cases, these collect-a-thons can be extremely time-consuming and very purposeful. It is perhaps for this reason that certain evolutions in this branch, such as Gimmighoul to Gholdengo, cannot be prevented as others can.

13 Battle-Based

Evolves: Bisharp, Primeape, Galarian Yamask, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon Legends: Arceus

Rather than leveling up on its own, which can be technically accomplished outside of battle, these evolutions specifically require the chosen Pokemon to participate in battles themselves. From there, the specifics of each required evolution differ drastically. In Legends: Arceus and for Primeape in Scarlet and Violet , a common method is using a specific attack 20 times. Other Pokemon, like White-Striped Basculin and Galarian Yamask, require taking a certain amount of damage without fainting to evolve. In Basculin's case, this specifically must be recoil damage.

Perhaps the most complex evolution in this category is Bisharp, which requires the Pokemon to defeat three other Bisharp that hold the leader's crests to evolve into Kingambit. It is generally advised to give a Bisharp a fighting type move like focus blast, brick break, or reversal to expedite this process, as steel-dark types are four times weaker against them. All in all, these various methods require a bit more extra attention than most, naturally making them far less convenient.

12 Beauty Factor

Evolves: Feebas

  • Originated in Pokemon: Ruby and Sapphire

Feebas existed as a Generation III counterpart to Magikarp, with an emphasis on gaining beauty rather than power (although Milotic certainly doesn't skimp in either department.) Prior to the introduction of the Prism Scale, the only way to evolve Feebas was by increasing its Beauty Factor to 170 through continued judgment in Pokemon Contests.

While not exceedingly difficult, this does require some cultivation, as certain factors such as nature, movesets, and specific items can all play a part in the ultimate result. In newer games, many of which no longer have contests, Feebas evolves by being traded with a Prism Scale, although later games with contests also utilize Beauty Factor as a possible method.

11 Union Circle Connection

Evolves: Finizen

  • Originated in Pokemon: Scarlet and Violet

Evolving Finizen into the elusive Palafin requires a continual connection with another player in the Union Circle. This may be somewhat more frustrating for players with poor internet connectivity, as the process of leveling up, while fairly simple on its own, can take a while depending on Finizen's current level.

The exact level of convenience can be premeditated to some extent. If a Finizen reaches a certain level (37 or higher) and the player has a rare candy at the ready, this can be wrapped up even shorter than a trade.

10 Setting-Based

Evolves: Eevee, Sliggoo, Tyrunt, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Gold and Silver

Some Pokemon only evolve at certain times of day. One Pokemon (Sliggoo) only evolves when it rains. These are a bit more difficult despite sounding somewhat easier, as time is never the sole requirement. These kinds of Pokemon often need a high enough level, a specific held item, or happiness to properly evolve.

9 Trading

Evolves: Haunter, Kadabra, Machoke, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Red and Blue

Trading is a central aspect to Pokemon, with the mainline games always being handheld, and connectable with other players' devices. It is a method that for a while was the only way to obtain fan-favorite Pokemon, such as Gengar or Alakazam. This common method, however, is somewhat less convenient, as it most commonly requires either another player or a separate console running a compatible game.

The difficulty is compounded when more further requirements like having a certain held item, or in one odd case, evolving opposite another specific Pokemon are included.

8 Let's Go!

Evolves: Rellor, Pawmo, and Bramblin

  • Originated in Pokemon: Scarlet and Violet

The Let's Go! feature introduced in Scarlet and Violet allows a trainer's Pokemon to accompany them in the overworld. Three Pokemon evolve after walking 1000 steps with this feature and leveling up. This can be done in essentially any walkable part of the overworld with relatively minimal effort.

It may be mildly less convenient for trainers who wish to ride on their legendary bike Pokemon, as this counter can be reset.

7 Location-Based

Evolves: Eevee, Magneton, Nosepass etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Diamond and Pearl

Generation IV included many new evolutions for established Pokemon for previous generations. Because of this, more complex evolution methods were ushered in, presumably to explain why these Pokemon could not evolve in earlier generations.

One such method is location-based evolutions, where Pokemon need to be near a certain type of area to evolve. A common example is a magnetic field which could evolve Nosepass, Magneton, and Charjabug. This method, while somewhat specific, is comparatively easy, as all it requires is to visit the location once it is accessible and train until they hit a level. Newer generations seem to have largely phased this method out, as now most Pokemon it affected can instead evolve by way of items, such as elemental stones.

6 Party-Based

Evolves: Mantyke, Nincada, and Pancham

  • Originated in Pokemon: Ruby and Sapphire

Some Pokemon only evolve if the party is right. These Pokemon all require leveling up, but need a specific Pokemon to be in or out of the party before they properly evolve. Shedinja is a special evolution of Nincada, who otherwise only evolves into Ninjask. If a player has a spare pokeball and party slot, a Shedinja appears once the evolution takes place.

Mantyke needs a Remoraid in the Party, which makes sense, as they tend to latch on to the evolved Mantine. Pancham needs a dark-type Pokemon in the party to evolve into Pangoro. These methods often require relatively minimal planning but are not as immediate or convenient as simply grinding to level up.

5 Move-Based

Evolves: Piloswine, Lickitung, Yanma, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Diamond and Pearl

Some Pokemon need to learn a move before they evolve. This requires leveling up in advance, but is often no more situational than leveling up before or after the move is learned. In fact, if a trainer simply wants a specific move that will incidentally level up a Pokemon, it is entirely possible to achieve this kind of evolution by accident.

Sylveon requires slightly more attention, needing a higher level of either affection or happiness, depending on the game, before evolving, whilst knowing baby-doll-eyes.

4 Happiness

Evolves: Eevee, Riolu, Pichu, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Gold and Silver

Many Pokemon evolve by maxing out friendship. There are many methods to do this, including leveling up a Pokemon at its met location, letting it hold a soothe bell, or capturing it with a luxury ball. However, certain items and actions will also reduce friendship, such as giving a Pokemon bitter medicine or having it faint in battle.

Ultimately, as long as you avoid bitter medicine and super-high-leveled Pokemon, friendship is fairly easy to increase and often includes many fringe benefits alongside evolution.

3 Spinning and Sweets

Evolves: Milcery

  • Originated in Pokemon: Sword and Shield

The cream Pokemon Milcery can evolve into one of several forms of Alcremie, all of which require spinning for an allotted amount of time (usually less than five seconds) with a specific held item. The evolution is fairly easy, getting the exact type of Alcremie you want is a bit less so.

Factors that determine evolution include; how long the player was spinning, whether the player spun clockwise or counterclockwise, what time of day it was, and what type of sweet was held. The Pokemon has 63 forms in total, with nine different cream bases, and seven different sweets to combine.

2 Leveling Up

Evolves: Bulbasaur, Charmander, Squirtle, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Red and Blue

Leveling up is perhaps the most common way to evolve a Pokemon, and is fairly easy. Just throw a Pokemon into battle against an opponent it can beat, and it will gain experience. It doesn't even need to finish it off, although this will give it more experience. For most other methods of evolution displayed thus far, leveling up is often an additional stipulation.

In newer games, which introduced the EXP Share, and later made it into an item that affects the whole party, leveling up a Pokemon has never been easier. Some Pokemon tend to need slightly more motivation to evolve, such as Inkay who needs the device turned upside down to evolve itself upon leveling up. Other Pokemon have different forms they can take upon leveling up, such as Tyrogue whose evolution depends on how its attack and defense stats are allocated.

1 Item-Based

Evolves: Pikachu, Eevee, Applin, etc.

  • Originated in Pokemon: Red and Blue

While not as common as leveling up, using items to evolve Pokemon is a continual method employed throughout the series. Most items are usually elemental stones, often corresponding to the element of the Pokemon in question.

However, recent games have introduced other items which Pokemon can be exposed to and evolve, such as the three apples Applin can be exposed to, in order to evolve. Pokemon can evolve with these items at any level, all that's often required is simply finding them and exposing the right Pokemon to them.

item.title: How to Get to Bonny Village in Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Find the Hidden Path to Bonny Village Through Moorth Ruins
  • What to Do in Bonny Village
  • Where to Go After Bonny Village

Exploration in Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree retains the key characteristics of the base game in all the best ways. Fake walls, hidden tunnels, and a confusing map are some of the biggest obstacles players will have to overcome to find everything there is to find in the DLC.

One of the locations that can be incredibly easy to miss, despite it being a central gateway to other places, is Bonny Village. Found in Scadu Altus, reaching Bonny Village requires taking a hidden path through Moorth Ruins.

How to Find the Hidden Path to Bonny Village Through Moorth Ruins

In Moorth Ruins, there are two paths leading underground. One of them is too steep a drop to jump down, which will always result in player death if you choose to jump in. The other path is a bit more hidden and can be taken to reach Bonny Village. Here is how to get there.

From Moorth Ruins Site of Grace (where you meet Dryleaf Dane), look for a large stone tower in the middle of the ruins. To the right of the tower, there is a broken-down building with a corpse and a purple item (Shadow Realm Rune). To the left of the item is a small opening that opens up a path underground. Following this linear tunnel will guide players directly to a ladder that leads to the entrance of Bonny Village.

There is a chest in this tunnel containing the Golden Arcs , one of the best incantations in the DLC.

What to Do in Bonny Village

After unlocking the Bonny Village Site of Grace, there are a few items of note to be found in the village:

  • Bonny Butchering Knife : A purple item on a corpse just before the broken bridge separating the two sections of the village.
  • Tooth Whip : Inside the Whipping Hut, located past the bridge heading northeast.
  • Revered Spirit Ash : On a statue at the far left of the ravine going through the middle of the village. Only visible from inside the ravine.
  • O Mother Gesture : Can be found directly north of the village. Used to open a secret pathway next to the Storehouse, Back Section Site of Grace.
  • 2x Hefty Cracked Pot : One Hefty Cracked pot is in the main part of the village, on a corpse sitting beside some large pots. The second one is on another corpse at the start of the second part of the village.

Where to Go After Bonny Village

After you’ve done everything there is to do in Bonny Village, there are two paths you can take:

  1. The southern bridge leads to Bonny Gaol, where you can find the Night Armor Set and the Curseblade Labirith Spirit Ashes .
  2. The eastern bridge leads to the Rabbath Rise Tower, the Cathedral of Manus Metyr, and the Church District. Going to the Church District is the only way to reach the Storehouse, Back Section in the Shadow Keep.

item.title: Wuthering Waves: All Frostbug Locations
item.description:
The 1.1 update of Wuthering Waves introduces players to an entirely new area with unique mechanics, Mt. Firmament. This area is filled with various interactive elements such as Windchimes, which are similar to Sonance Caskets, along with numerous puzzles and supply chests for players to discover and collect. In addition to these features, players will encounter Frostbugs, which serve as the area's counterpart to Blobflies and contribute significantly to the overall exploration progress.

To maximize exploration points and rewards, players need to find and hit these Frostbugs, each of which grants 20 Asterite. While collecting all 10 Frostbugs in Mt. Firmament, players should pay attention to specific details to ensure they gather them quickly.

How to Collect Frostbugs in Wuthering Waves?

While locating and collecting Frostbugs might be easier than Blobflies, since players don’t need to wait long to hit them again if they miss their opportunity, certain details still require attention. If players get too close to a Frostbug, it will hide, making it impossible to collect. Therefore, it's recommended to keep a distance until the Frostbug emerges from its hole and use a ranged character like Chixia or Aalto to hit them.

Additionally, even when hit, Frostbugs won't be collected if they are not struck from the correct angle. Their weak spot is right under their head from the back, so players should position themselves behind the Frostbug and aim at the small marker.

All Frostbug Locations in Wuthering Waves

There are a total of 10 Frostbug spots, and collecting the first one as well as all 10 will grant achievements. All Frostbugs are located in open air, not in caves, and players will likely encounter them while exploring for chests and windchimes. Most Frostbug spots have three breakable ice blocks surrounding them, making them easier to locate. Here are all the locations:

Frostbug 1

Slightly Northeast of Resonance Beacon at Xuanji Ridges inside a spring pool.

Frostbug 2

Jump down from south of Resonance Nexus near Hongzen. Located in a spring at the bottom level.

Frostbug 3

On a small island on the shoreline where two longer islands connect.

Frostbug 4

Teleport to the south western Resonance Beacon of Loong's Ridge, move to the nearby broken bridge. Visible from top, and it's located at the bottom of the waterfall.

Frostbug 5

From the more eastern Resonance Beacon from the previous one, head south and jump down to the shore. Located at the small island on the map.

Frostbug 6

Teleport to the most eastern Resonance Beacon in Loong's Ridge, and go to south east to find it by the shore.

Frostbug 7

Head to the Resonance Beacon on the bottom level in Loong's Ridge, go through the tunnel towards east, use grappler (or climb) to find the Frostbug on a rock at the middle level.

Frostbug 8

At the end of the river by a waterfall on the north of the map.

Frostbug 9

On a rounded shoreline on the north side. Hard to miss.

Frostbug 10

Following west from the previous one, on a small mini island right at the edge. Hard to miss.
